title: The Energy Transition and the Securitisation of Materials and Supply Chains.
text:
What



Panel discussion








Where



Online, hosted by Chatham House



Overview
Chatham House’s Environment and Society Centre Beyond Energy Transition: How will industries be transformed? series aimed to enhance understanding of the interplay between the energy transition and its broader geopolitical implications.
The third in the series aimed to discuss how different countries are reacting to concerns over access to critical materials.
I raised three main points: 1. We should better internalise the environmental costs vs the previous fossil fuel based system; 2. Centre justice in the transition; 3. Reducing demand through the circular economy is by far the most powerful method of reducing social and environmental costs and securing supply chains.

title: Equity in energy transition: ensuring a just and inclusive path forward.
text:
What



Panel discussion








Where



Future of Utilities Energy Transition Summit 2024: SugarFactory, Amsterdam, Netherlands








For



Senior utilities leaders, policy makers and investors



Overview
The summit brings together senior leaders from incumbents, innovators, policy makers and investors to advance the transition towards a renewable energy ecosystem.

“It’s the energy conference for decision-makers committed to accelerating Europe’s energy transition.”

On the panel, we tackled a number of questions:

Bearing the cost of transition: how can costs be distributed equitably amongst customers and stakeholders?
A transition for all: exploring strategies to ensure nationwide access to clean energy
The price question: how can the cost of green technology be managed for vulnerable customers?
The power of community energy: what benefits can it bring to local communities?
Protecting the environment: how can businesses mitigate the impact of new infrastructure?
The bigger picture: what more could governments and regulators do to ensure a just transition?

title: Managing People and Nature in Urban Environments
text:
What



Lecture








Where



Imperial College London








For



Urban Sustainable Environment option students on the Environmental Technology MSc.



Overview
The lecture draws on my experience with the London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham and the London National Park City campaign. It outlines the importance of urban ecology, and the need to integrate with global biodiversity processes. It highlights some of the main challenges in managing urban spaces for nature before presenting some possible solutions.

title: Nature-based solutions: the Conventions on Climate & Biodiversity
text:
Preview image by Matthias Mullie on Unsplash.







What



Panel with presentation








Where



Online








For



Jointly hosted by the Chartered Institute of Ecology and Environmental Management (CIEEM), the Royal Society for Biology (RSB), and the Institution of Environmental Sciences (IES).



Overview
Towards the end of 2021, leaders from around the world will meet in Kunming and Glasgow to discuss the Convention on Biological Diversity and the Convention on Climate Change at COP15 and COP26 respectively. In those conversations, the role of nature will be paramount. Nature-based solutions will play an integral role in the fight against climate change, which has made them one of the key presidential themes for COP26. Nature also underpins the ecological emergency which is interlinked with the climate crisis.
This panel event will place the COP26 theme of nature-based solutions within the context of the wider sustainability agenda, especially the upcoming COP15 for the Convention on Biological Diversity. Our expert panellists will link the two Conventions and their conferences through the lens of nature and nature-based solutions, giving attendees insights into what they should expect ahead of COP15, the links between the two conferences, and the importance of nature as a key element of both high-level discussions.
A time-stamped recording of the event is here.

title: Welcome!
text:
Dr Sebastian Dunnett is a nature scientist and IPBES biodiversity expert with a PhD in renewable energy and biodiversity and significant experience helping organisations deliver sustainability objectives. Seb is currently working to ensure businesses contribute to global biodiversity goals, as well as advocating for nature in a just energy transition.

“I care to live only to entice people to look at Nature’s loveliness.”
John Muir

title: Bulldozing biodiversity? Conservation with the private sector.
text:
What



Policy Seminar








Where



Centre for Environmental Policy, Imperial College London








For



Environmental Technology master’s students



Overview
The human race is two thirds of the way to having the same impact on biodiversity in their short lifetime on Earth than a 112-mile wide asteroid. Businesses often shoulder the lion’s share of the blame for this. They undeniably have wide-reaching and substantial impacts on biodiversity, and are often accused of having undue influence on policy. However, they also offer an important lever for change. This talk will present UNEP-WCMC’s work engaging the private sector, primarily the extractive industries, before giving real world examples of the science-government-business interface and implications for conservation.

title: Building a Career in Climate
text:
What



Careers event








Where



Online








For



Terra.do community



Overview
Presentation followed by a Q&A covering the following aspects of building a career in climate:

What is your current climate role?
What was your professional background and how did it lead you here?
What is unique about working in your sector?
What are some less-known challenges that affect your sector?
What climate solution are you most excited about?
What are the kinds of projects and skills that are most in demand in your sector?
Where do you most see opportunity for individuals looking to enter your sector?

title: Acheiving Europe’s renewable energy targets while protecting nature.
text:
What



Pop up panel discussion








Where



Eurelectric’s Power Summit 2023: Maison de la Poste, Brussels, Belgium








For



Energy sector professionals



Overview
Europe is now negotiating a landmark law to restore damaged environments. But that’s running into opposition from those who see a contradiction between nature protection and energy and food security. Looking ahead, the EU is set to triple the build out of wind and solar capacity by 2030. Can Europe fight both crises?
Last year, Eurelectric launched the PowerPlant project focused on reshaping the public discourse. The goal is to promote integrated RES and infrastructure projects, which serve to both speed up the decarbonisation of the energy system and contribute to regenerate some of the 81% of habitats which are degraded across the EU.
Within this context, ensuring an optimal spatial planning is the first step to both minimise the impact on nature while providing visibility for renewables developers. Based on the recently agreed renewables permitting framework, by mid-2024 EU Member States are mandated to map all land and water surfaces needed to reach their 2030 renewable energy objectives. Optimal zoning will require combined nature and energy planning based on data-driven intelligence and involving all the relevant stakeholders in a timely manner.
The panelists will explore various solutions to tackle the climate and biodiversity crisis together, including:

How can we avoid impact on environmental sensitive areas while reaching the 2030 EU RES targets?
What methodologies should Member States follow when mapping renewables suitable areas?
What role for data-driven intelligence to ensure a sound energy transition planning?
What is the electricity sector doing to minimise their impact on nature? And what is the necessary enabling framework to scale it up?





CitationBibTeX citation:@online{dunnett2023,
  author = {Dunnett, Seb},
  title = {Acheiving {Europe’s} Renewable Energy Targets While
    Protecting Nature.},

title: Addressing global biodiversity loss.
text:
What



Panel discussion








Where



UCL Sustainability Leadership Conference 2024, Marshagte, UCL East Campus








For



University students



Overview
The Sustainability Leadership Conference, co-delivered by Sustainable UCL and Students’ Union UCL, brought together students, experts, and organisations to discuss the biggest issue facing the world today, and how to tackle it.
On the panel, I laid out government and policy solutions to global biodiversity loss, talking about the crucial role of IPBES in supporting evidence-based policy, the UN Biodiversity Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework and the importance of connecting global policy to local action.
